EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

Accidental Release Prevention 

Northern California Power Agency (NCPA) Combustion Turbines has developed a Risk Management Program and an Emergency Response Plan to address RMP and CalARP Program requirements. NCPA Combustion Turbines has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia Injection System. NCPA - Combustion Turbines' policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

 NCPA Combustion Turbines is located at 12745 North Thornton Rd, Lodi, California 95242. The regulated substance at the Facility is anhydrous ammonia. The maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 10,200 gallons (52,530 pounds [lbs]) and it is stored in a pressurized horizontal storage vessel at ambient temperature in liquid form. The amount of anhydrous ammonia corresponds to the 85% capacity of V-3401, as the facility implements administrative controls that limit the maximum filling of the tanks to 85% of the capacity. When ambient conditions do not significantly promote the vaporization of liquid ammonia, a vaporizer is utilized to heat the liquid to its boiling point to produce vapor. The vapor ammonia is sent to a mixing chamber where it is mixed with air. The resulting vapor ammonia / air stream is then injected into the Heat Recovery Steam Generator (HRSG). This, in conjunction with the catalyst within the HRSG, allow for the reduction of NOx and other unwanted materials being sent to the environment. The exhaust gas containing a lower concentration of NOx is then sent from the HRSG to an exhaust stack. 

Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis 

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary: Per CalARP Regulations and US EPA RMP Regulations, one wor

st-case analysis has been defined and modeled for the Ammonia Injection System. The results can be found in the 2023 Hazard Assessment documentation.

 Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary: An alternative release scenario was modeled. The results can be found in the 2023 Hazard Assessment documentation.

 Risk Considerations 

Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; NCPA has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible. In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent. Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model). In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release, including the following automatic / manual shutdown, ammonia sensors in the process area, SCADA system, Continous Emissions Monitoring System (CEMS), well designed relief system, safety showers/eye wash stations, Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), the system undergoes periodic maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.

Accidental Release Prevention Program 

Key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by NCPA to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia. Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to

ensure safe practices are being performed. The covered process has over the 10,000-lb threshold quantity for US EPA RMP and Cal/OSHA PSM threshold quantities, and over the 500-lb state threshold for CalARP Program. As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3, US EPA RMP Program Level 3, and Cal/OSHA PSM. 

The Anhydrous Ammonia Prevention Program 3 elements include: Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Management of Change, Pre-Startup Safety Review, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, Employee Participation, Hot Work Permit, and Contractors. In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed the Program.

Five-Year Accident History 

For any accidental release meeting the five-year accident history reporting criteria of 19 CCR §2750.9 and 40 CFR § 68.36 , the owner or operator shall submit the data required under 19 CCR §2745.5, §2745.6, and §2745.7 with respect to that accident within six months of the release or by the time the RMP is updated under 19 CCR §2745.10, whichever is earlier. From 19 CCR §2750.9: "The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage." There have been no RMP/CalARP-applicable releases of ammonia at NCPA Combustion Turbines in the past five years. 


Emergency Response Program 

NCPA  Combustion Turbines is a responding facility. The facility has implemented an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that meets applicable requirements for on-site emergencies. Employees are trained to extent needed for their responsibilities. NCPA  Combustion Turbines also coordinates with local Fire Department and other first responders. The Plant Manager and Compliance Manager maintain th

e ERP that provides the response protocols and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which have been implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. The ERP is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with CalARP and ERP regulations. Key elements of the ERP include: Emergency Alarm Procedures, Evacuation Procedures, Safety and Health Considerations, Notification Procedures, Incident Sizing, and Response Procedures.

External Events Analysis Information 

The 2020 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) report discusses applicable and relevant external events. In addition, a Seismic Assessment was conducted to estimate the magnitude or scope of seismic activity in relation to the facility components. The most recent field verification of equipment was conducted on August 7, 2020 and included the piping system. A seismic safety walk-down was performed June 9, 2021. All findings are documented in the 2021 Seismic Assessment report.

Planned Changes To Improve Safety 

The PHA study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility. Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the 2020 PHA Report, if any. 

Flammables: Worst Case 

The use of flammable materials at NCPA Combustion Turbines is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements. Therefore, this section is not applicable.
